Introduction

Barrett esophagus is a pathologic alteration of the distal esophagus lining in which the normal stratified squamous epithelium is replaced by a specialized columnar epithelium.  This condition is strongly associated with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and markedly increases the risk for esophageal adenocarcinoma compared to the general population.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The development of Barrett esophagus is closely related to persistent acid reflux, in which repeated exposure to acidic gastric contents leads to chronic inflammation and epithelial injury in the lower esophagus.  Over time, the damaged squamous epithelium is replaced by more acid-resistant, intestinal-type columnar cells (

image 1
).  Although this metaplasia may initially be an adaptive response (ie, intestinal-type epithelium is more resistant to gastric acid), it carries a heightened risk for malignant transformation, ultimately giving rise to esophageal adenocarcinoma.  The overall annual cancer risk is low (0.3%-0.5%), although the likelihood varies with the degree of dysplasia (discussed later).



Key risk factors for Barrett esophagus include:



  • Chronic GERD (eg, >5 years).
  • Age >50.
  • Family history.
  • Central obesity.
  • White patient.
  • Tobacco use.

Clinical presentation



Many individuals with Barrett esophagus are asymptomatic or have symptoms indistinguishable from those of GERD (eg, heartburn, acid regurgitation).  Because these manifestations are not specific, Barrett esophagus is often diagnosed incidentally during endoscopic evaluations for long-standing reflux symptoms or complications (eg, esophageal strictures).

Diagnosis

Screening recommendations



Endoscopic screening is considered in patients without known Barrett esophagus if multiple risk factors for adenocarcinoma are present.  These include chronic GERD, male sex, age â‰¥50, White patient, hiatal hernia, tobacco use, and a family history of Barrett esophagus or esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Endoscopic findings



On endoscopy, Barrett esophagus is suggested by the appearance of salmon-colored, velvety mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction, contrasting with the surrounding pale squamous epithelium.  Histopathologic confirmation requires identifying intestinal metaplasia, specifically goblet cells (

image 2
).



Progression from nondysplastic Barrett esophagus to esophageal adenocarcinoma typically follows a sequence of increasing dysplasia:



  • No dysplasia:  <1% risk per year for malignancy.
  • Low-grade dysplasia:  Higher risk than nondysplastic Barrett esophagus.
  • High-grade dysplasia:  Significantly elevated cancer risk (4%-8% per year).

Management

General principles



The primary approach to managing Barrett esophagus centers on controlling GERD and minimizing acid-related esophageal injury.  Lifelong proton pump inhibitor therapy is generally recommended to:



  • Alleviate reflux symptoms (eg, heartburn, epigastric discomfort).
  • Prevent ongoing acid-induced mucosal damage.
  • Reduce the risk for malignant transformation.


Lifestyle modificationsâ€”losing weight, making dietary adjustments, stopping smoking, and elevating the head of the bedâ€”support pharmacologic therapy.  In cases in which GERD symptoms persist despite optimal medical management, surgical interventions (eg, fundoplication) may be considered.

Nondysplastic vs dysplastic disease



In nondysplastic Barrett esophagus, periodic endoscopic surveillance (eg, every 3-5 years) is recommended.



Management escalates when dysplasia is detected (

figure 1
):



  • Low-grade dysplasia:  Closer endoscopic surveillance (eg, every 6-12 months) or endoscopic eradication therapy (eg, radiofrequency ablation, cryotherapy, photodynamic therapy), with eradication increasingly favored.
  • High-grade dysplasia:  Endoscopic eradication therapy or, in rare cases, esophagectomy is recommended.


Esophageal adenocarcinoma is discussed in more detail in a separate article.

Summary



Barrett esophagus (

) is a premalignant condition characterized by the replacement of normal esophageal squamous epithelium with specialized columnar epithelium due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease.  Affecting 10%-15% of patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease, Barrett esophagus significantly increases the risk for esophageal adenocarcinoma.  Key risk factors include chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, age >50, obesity, White patient, and family history.  Diagnosis involves endoscopic visualization of salmon-colored esophageal mucosa and histopathologic confirmation of intestinal metaplasia (ie, goblet cells).  Management focuses on long-term acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors, lifestyle modifications, and periodic endoscopic surveillance.  Dysplastic disease warrants more aggressive interventions, namely, endoscopic eradication therapy.
